ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: My ability to read and interpret graphs of functions improved a lot. I also got better at doing integrals and learned a ton of new specific multivariable information.
I learned how to do multivariable calculus.
Multivariable calculus! And how to think about math both geometrically/physically and algebraically

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I felt that I learned too much from the videos and not enough from lecture. The lecture was way too boring for anyone to be engaged and that in turn caused a lot of people, me included, to be confused by the material.

I thought this was a really strong course. It moves really quickly at the beginning of the semester and I thought that was a little overwhelming. But generally I liked the order we learned the material in and really enjoyed this class.
The instructor was incredible and it gave a great geometric understanding on math concepts

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Videos were very helpful. I thought they actually did a great job moving the course online.

The videos on canvas were great.
The zoom lecture was not so great.
I thought pre-recorded lectures for homework worked really well. I would have appreciated an optional section once a week where we could have worked on solving problems in small groups.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would not recommend this class to anyone that doesn't need to take it. A lot of the time the math only seems to apply to physics.

Yes! Even if this course is not required for your major, I think the information is all super interesting and fun. I think this class also really improved my quantitative reasoning and generally made me more comfortable working with complicated math topics.
To be honest, I wouldn't recommend Math 120 to another student if it's not a requirement for your major.
Yes! Though it was difficult I learned a lot

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: I usually just watched the videos on canvas, those were the most helpful
I also attended weekly coaching sessions and watched recorded lectures for homework.
I looked at the textbook a lot and at Ximera
